Events.RelatedDescription: Reopened issue "Allow control of Sorting when searching from PMUI" (#7992) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.
NuGet Client request to allow sorting on the Browse tab will require Server changes as well.

### Describe the solution you'd like
What changes would be necessary on Server to handle such a feature? Perhaps it should be limited to a single source?

### Additional context
https://github.com/nuget/home/issues/2585

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "PackageReference restore in Visual Studio should not spam the status bar" (#9915) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Today, when restoring in Visual Studio, when doing an actual restore or solution load restore, NuGet writes *a lot* of messages at the status bar. 

There's a bunch of messages such as "restore packages for" and "writing assets file for" which are pretty equivalent. 
In extreme cases this can lead up to 3-4 messages per projects, so you sometimes end up with 300 messages in a 15s restore. 

It's difficult to interpret all these messages, they are not very useful from a customer perspective. 

My suggestion is to reduce the number of messages, or potentially removing them completely. 

cc @JonDouglas 

Related to this, we considered https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/9396, but it has bugs and is not suitable when *restore* is very quick.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Remove workaround account for some .NET 5 SDKs report TargetPlatformMoniker of ` ,Version= `" (#9913) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Different SDKs set a different TargetPlatformMoniker. 
For example .NET 5 P8 and earlier would report ` ,Version=` as TPM for the net50 TPV.
That was later fixed in https://github.com/dotnet/msbuild/commit/9389d843ab9c291c7bb75fbb4f9302f99224c29b. 

In order to not run into problems with this, a hack was added in https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/pull/3578. 

This issue tracks the revert of that hack.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "NuGet Target framework information breaking change coordination" (#9911) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
In 16.8 P2, NuGet made a breaking change where we started reading the TargetFramework* and TargetPlatform* properties from the inner build.
This means that the framework detection across NuGet & SDK needed to change. 

In additional .NET 5 SDK, P7 and earlier, misreported the TargetPlatformMoniker for net5.0 projects as `Windows,Version=7.0`. 

Other notable challenges are that in 16.8 P2, NuGet used TargetPlatformIdentifier and TargetPLatformVersion, but in 16.8 P3 NuGet will use TargetPlatformMoniker. https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/pull/3578. 

So this is meant to coordinate the insertions necessary to get 16.8 P2 and 16.8 P3 in a happy state. 

- [ ] NuGet -> VS (16.8 P2)
- [ ] NuGet -> SDK (.NET 5 P8 & .NET 5 RC1)
- [ ] VS -> SDK (.NET 5 P8 with NuGet to VS 16.8 P2)
- [ ] NuGet -> project-system (16.8 P2) https://github.com/dotnet/project-system/pull/6495 - This allows NuGet in VS 16.8 P2 and 16.8 P3 to work continuously. 
- [ ] project-system -> VS (16.8 P2) 

cc @zkat

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Created a tech spec for Embedded Readmes" (#9832) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody: Created an implementation spec for the Embedded Readmes feature [[Issue 9752](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/9752)].

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Bug Bash][Test Failure] Warning icons show on the installed packages in Console App (.NET Core 5.0) project" (#9910) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem
NuGet version: NuGet Client Dev\5.8.0.6776
VS Version: Master\30413.119
OS: Windows-10-Enterprise-RS5
## Detailed repro steps 
1. Create a C# Console App (.NET Core) project in VS.
2. Open the project PM UI and the Solution Explorer window.
3. Install several packages from PM UI into the project.
4. Check the “Dependencies->Packages” node in the Solution Explorer window.
## Expected
No warning icons show on the installed package.
## Actual
Warning icons show on the installed packages in Console App (.NET Core 5.0) project but there is no warning in Error List window as below screenshot.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20632625/90264971-81072580-de84-11ea-9e37-d2a64a649a1b.png)
## Notes
1. It repro on ASP Web Application (.NET Core 5.0), but not repro on Class Library (.NET Standard 2.1) project.
2. It didn’t repro when creating the .NET Core 5.0 project (so it is not the bug 1165638), repro after installing packages.
3. It didn’t repro on VS Master\30411.167 + NuGet Client Dev\5.8.0.6776, but repro on Master\30413.119 with implicit NuGet Client Dev\5.8.0.6776.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "File not found when pushing snupkg vi Nuget.exe and dotnet nuget push" (#9909) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem
When I try to push a *.snupkg to our corporate nexus server it fail with the file not found error. But the file is on a mentioned path and I can open it with winzip. I try it via Nuget.exe and with dotnet.exe with the same result. When I push standard nupkg everything works fine on V2 and also for V3 protokol.

Nuget.exe and dotnet.exe

NuGet version: 5.6.0, 5.7.0 5.8.0-preview.1

dotnet.exe --version (if appropriate):3.1.401

VS version (if appropriate): 16.7.1

OS version: Windows 10 1809

Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version: No it's my first try to push symbols to our corporate nexus feed.

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1. dotnet new classlib
2. dotnet pack -p:IncludeSymbols=true -p:SymbolPackageFormat=snupkg
3. nuget push C:\FULL_PATH_TO_PROJECT\bin\Debug\TestLibrary.1.0.0.snupkg -Source CorporateNexus -SymbolSource CorporateNexus -verbosity detailed  -ForceEnglishOutput

...
### Verbose Logs
```
nuget push C:\FULL_PATH_TO_PROJECT\bin\Debug\TestLibrary.1.0.0.snupkg -Source CorporateNexus -SymbolSource CorporateNexus -verbosity detailed  -ForceEnglishOutput
NuGet Version: 5.6.0.6591
File does not exist (C:\FULL_PATH_TO_PROJECT\bin\Debug\TestLibrary.1.0.0.snupkg).
System.ArgumentException: File does not exist (C:\FULL_PATH_TO_PROJECT\TestLibrary\bin\Debug\KB.TestLibrary.1.0.0.snupkg).
   at NuGet.Protocol.Core.Types.PackageUpdateResource.<PushSymbols>d__17.MoveNext()
--- End of stack trace from previous location where exception was thrown ---
   at System.Runtime.ExceptionServices.ExceptionDispatchInfo.Throw()
   at System.Runtime.CompilerServices.TaskAwaiter.HandleNonSuccessAndDebuggerNotification(Task task)
   at NuGet.Protocol.Core.Types.PackageUpdateResource.<Push>d__14.MoveNext()
--- End of stack trace from previous location where exception was thrown ---
   at System.Runtime.ExceptionServices.ExceptionDispatchInfo.Throw()
   at System.Runtime.CompilerServices.TaskAwaiter.HandleNonSuccessAndDebuggerNotification(Task task)
   at NuGet.Commands.PushRunner.<Run>d__0.MoveNext()
--- End of stack trace from previous location where exception was thrown ---
   at System.Runtime.ExceptionServices.ExceptionDispatchInfo.Throw()
   at System.Runtime.CompilerServices.TaskAwaiter.HandleNonSuccessAndDebuggerNotification(Task task)
   at NuGet.CommandLine.PushCommand.<ExecuteCommandAsync>d__36.MoveNext()
--- End of stack trace from previous location where exception was thrown ---
   at System.Runtime.ExceptionServices.ExceptionDispatchInfo.Throw()
   at System.Runtime.CompilerServices.TaskAwaiter.HandleNonSuccessAndDebuggerNotification(Task task)
   at NuGet.CommandLine.Command.Execute()
   at NuGet.CommandLine.Program.MainCore(String workingDirectory, String[] args)
```

What I did wrong?

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "CVE-2020-1340 - NuGet Gallery Spoofing Vulnerability" (#45) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
A spoofing vulnerability exists when the NuGet Gallery does not properly sanitize input on package metadata values. An attacker who successfully exploited the vulnerability could perform cross-site scripting attacks and run scripts in the security context of the user viewing the malicious content.

To exploit this vulnerability, an attacker with permissions to upload packages could publish specially crafted content on a gallery page.

The security update addresses the vulnerability by correcting how NuGet Gallery sanitizes input.

**MSRC Security Guidance:** [CVE-2020-1340](https://portal.msrc.microsoft.com/en-US/security-guidance/advisory/CVE-2020-1340)
**Security Update:** [v2020.06.09](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/releases/tag/v2020.06.09)
